page.title: 07OVER WYRESDALE:DAIRY FARMING
page.content: Friesians are the most popular breed but there is a North American and a Holstein influence introduced by the use of artificial insemination which produces larger animals.The basic diet of the large herds (20 to 100 head) is grass and silage, whereas the smaller units are fed on hay. This diet is supplemented by purchased concentrates. Because of E.E.C. quotas each farmer's milk production was cut by 10% in 1984. Farmers have reacted to these cuts by reducing cow numbers or by reducing costs. One way to do this is to purchase 'straights' i.e. concentrates before the miller has mixed them and added his costs. The price paid for milk in 1985 is 15p per litre but this does vary with quality. Because this area is so wet farmers have to house cattle and provide indoor feed longer than elsewhere.
